- Egotistical, incompetent managers who only care about Diversity & Inclusion for image
- Little to no job mobility; promotions take AT LEAST 6 mo-1 year to process even before pandemic
- Extremely emotionally draining and demoralizing

review_title: Underpaid, sometimes cliquish, but some great people
pros: There's a huge sense of community here, and the staff as a whole really love it here. The students are genuinely great, the least entitled I've ever worked with in higher ed. You can't beat the location, and if you're into the arts, there's no better environment for it.
cons: Staff are woefully underpaid, from below market to way, way below market. HR is dreadful and overstaffed, while all other departments are understaffed. There's definitely cliquishness in some areas, and folks who worked in non-Emerson schools often have their experiences dismissed as irrelevant. Work-life balance is bad here; you're expected to love Emerson enough to work on nights and weekends, and since so many staff are alums, they don't question it.

pros: Great public reputation and national profile.
cons: Literally everything else is undesirable.

job_title: Assistant Graphic Designer in Boston, MA
pros: Emerson is a fun, talent-filled environment where you will meet and work with all sort of interesting people. This is, of course, a college, so many of the jobs naturally revolve around academics, but there are also opportunities to work in departments that make truly excellent contributions to theater, radio and literature in Boston.
cons: The reality is that Emerson is a not-for-profit college that in many ways functions like a for-profit entity. The tuition is outrageous, and the contribution to Emerson from both the city of Boston and wealthy donors have been deep. Unfortunately, this doesn't have much of a trickle down. Those at the top are paid exorbitantly, while adjuncts and those low on the totem pole in administration and marketing are nickel and dimed. And this is in a city where the cost of living is sky high! Furthermore, your ability to advance may often be hampered by politics, no matter how hard you work.

pros: Because of their tuition remission for full-time employees, getting a degree while working full-time and without going into debt is feasible. The location right next to Boston Common is wonderful. The faculty is amazing and dedicated to the students despite working under an incompetent administration and a union-busting president.
cons: Within the upper administration, there are power struggles that seem to blind the administrators to the fact that they are ultimate serving the students. At the level that is one tier down from the top administrators, there is virtually no oversight whatsoever. Without oversight, support staff are essentially working in a dictatorship with no recourse and under managers who only do enough not to get fired and simply try to justify the existence of their position without actually accomplishing anything.

review_title: Emerson College is a great community to work in
job_title: Vice President for Public Affairs in Boston, MA
pros: At Emerson faculty and staff work cooperatively to enhance educational opportunities and experiences for students. There is a shared sense of mission and purpose and a belief that "we are all in this together." I've worked at five colleges and universities, and Emerson is the best of the bunch in terms of the work environment and ethic.
cons: If you are not interested in communications and the arts, Emerson may not be the best fit for you. There's a certain quirkiness to some aspects of the college and the way things are done. There is also a bit of insularity in some quarters and a notion that thing have to done "the Emerson way."

review_title: Amazing place to be as a student, and pretty neutral/comparable to other places as a professional environment.
pros: People are open-minded and friendly. They're committed to creating safe spaces for discussion and inclusion. Everyone is passionate and values creativity. You'll feel like you're doing work that matters.
cons: Tons of red tape. Honestly, that's the only real thing. Great work environment, but whenever something's wrong, it's nearly impossible to know whose job it is to fix it and go to them. It can take months to bring about change, and sometime the people up top may not give a good reason for why they decided not to change anything at all. Happens in a handful of departments, not all.

review_title: Read the contract and do not take verbal agreements
pros: The Students ara amazing, as are the professors. It's in the heart of Boston and amazing as a service provider. the mission of the school is great.
cons: The administration of the school tends to be patronizing. There is too much burocracy and there are things that arent coverd in the contracts that the staff has to do. There is little room for growing and especially part time employees get little or no benefits, but they have the same amount of responsability as full time staff.

review_title: Enriching because of the strength and friendliness of certain employees.
job_title: Systems and Network Technician in Boston, MA
pros: They hired me into IT Infrastructure after I had been a student employee for 3 years. I had no experience with most of the things in the job description, but they had faith I could learn. I got on-the-job experience that put me on my dream career path.
cons: As with many higher-ed institutions, dead weight tends to stick around. There are some people working at Emerson who are just plain useless, but hey will never be fired because the college is afraid of lawsuits.

review_title: Enriching because of the strength and friendliness of certain employees.
pros: They hired me into IT Infrastructure after I had been a student employee for 3 years. I had no experience with most of the things in the job description, but they had faith I could learn. I got on-the-job experience that put me on my dream career path.
cons: As with many higher-ed institutions, dead weight tends to stick around. There are some people working at Emerson who are just plain useless, but hey will never be fired because the college is afraid of lawsuits.

review_title: A positive exprience, though salary was too low
pros: I worked with amazing people and had the opportunity to work on very meaningful projects. It might be true that if I stayed for longer my salary would raise.
cons: The wage was too low, and there were no benefits at all. I was given complicated responsibilities, beyond my job description, and while it was good for my resume, it would have been nice to be compensated as well.

review_title: An abundance of opportunities to learn - more outside than in the classroom
pros:
A student will discover interest and skills in an area they had no idea they liked or existed.
Boston is truly you campus while at Emerson. It's the most amazing experience.
Students learn from both professors and each other. 
As an alumni people often describe you being so good because "she went to emerson"
cons: So much is learned outside the classroom that grades are sometimes weaker and that doesn't translate well for grad school.

pros: Friendly staff and students, good atmosphere
cons: too many emails, hard to figure out when scheduled requirements need to happen by - you often get an email the day of, or the day before, that there's something going on that you have to attend to. or worse yet, you miss a deadline because no one told you.

review_title: Worked at IT: Very professional for a mostly student-run organization
pros: The environment at Emerson IT was fun and chill, and I learned a lot more about computers and tech while working this job as a student. Tons of opportunities to request private training in various IT skills, despite your experience level or job title.
cons: The hours could be rough for certain colleagues, even borderline illegal with back to back full shifts with just an hour "break" in between (tho these schedules were assigned to students who requested them, insisting that they needed more money with our hourly wage system).

pros: An on-the-rise school that's attracting smart faculty, staff and students. The facilities are fantastic, the equipment is all top-notch, and there's a real desire on the part of almost everyone to do good work. A realistic approach toward learning is also excellent -- this isn't a research institution; it's a place where people learn how to get stuff done.
cons: Nothing beyond the same issues you encounter at any higher-ed position. It's not a utopia, but it's certainly not bad either.

pros: The college itself is hip, fun and clearly instills a hard-working culture. That translates very well into the work life as well. The health benefits are good, pay is fair, and overall its an exciting place to work with friendly staff.
cons: Typical higher-ed bureaucracy. Sometimes it takes a long time to get things done or approved. Seems to be a hard place to move up because higher level positions are rarely open.

pros: Great people and community to work for. Amazing benefits. The job is very interesting and fun to learn. Fun to be right in the city.
cons: BORING! Should only be a 6 month position. Nothing to do during the summer. Pay is terrible. Very cliquey here. You will feel the lowest of the low.

pros: Emerson has an eclectic campus culture with a strong leaning towards social justice. This shared sense of purpose permeated through the staff and student culture and brought both staff and students together.
cons: Pay didn't reflect this common goal and was left in theory. When the new president was hired his huge mansion seemed to come at a greater priority than raising the standard of living for staff.

pros: High level of professional and career individuals who went on to become faculty afterwards.  College is well-equipped with film, video, production, post, studios and audio equipment.  Performing Arts program has outstanding performance spaces.
cons: Politics play a role in many things as they do in most of academia.  Urban campus limits available space for expansion.

pros: The students are creative, driven, ambitious. They want to do well and are willing to work for it.
cons: As a whole Emerson is lagging behind in it's tangible plans to increase diversity and inclusivity at Emerson.

job_title: Part-Time Faculty Member in Boston, MA
pros: Adjuncts were formed in a union, provided office space and respected alongside permanent faculty members.
cons: Part of the general problem with adjunct professors in higher education--good pay for temporary adjunct work but still too low viz. permanent, tenure and tenure-track professors, and too easy to let go.

review_title: Great college work as a teaching assistant
pros: Great atmosphere to work alongside your professors and get insights into their job. They are extremely helpful and know that your degree comes first and will work around your schedule.
cons: It all comes down to which professor you are working for. As all things in life, some are others not so much.

pros: Emerson College has an incredible group of people, in every department, working together to make an incredible experience. The benefits are also quite good!
cons: It is right downtown, so you'd need to go downtown every day, but I got used to it!

review_title: An energetic and interesting place to work!
pros: Incredibly smart and talented staff and faculty, good benefits, challenging working environment.
cons: Modest salary for entry level position, day-to-day work can get very hectic, company can take a long time to get logistical matters and approvals taken care of.

pros: Great company culture. Friendly and dedicated staff. Good opportunity for students trying to make a little extra money.
cons: Salary was low. That's about it really, I enjoyed my time working here tremendously.

job_title: Senior Writer In Residence in Boston, MA
pros: Innovative, committed, driven students who are young artists hungry for help to achieve their goals.
cons: A two-tier faculty system that has one group of full-time professors doing twice the work for half the money.

review_title: Nice place, a bit isolating for adjuncts
pros: I enjoyed teaching, and they department was very supportive.
cons: Students have a lot going on (performances, politics,  paid jobs) and classes are not their focus.  I don't interact much with the other faculty or admin, so its a bit isolating.

review_title: Amazing teamwork, excellent benefits, supportive environment
pros: A workplace that is always striving to do the best it can for its employees with what it has
cons: It's a non-profit, so the salaries are a bit stagnant, and depending on where you work, there isn't always room for growth

review_title: Love teaching, but it comes at a price ($$$)
pros: Wonderful students, flexible schedule. Great location, a nice place to work. Lots of opportunities for mentoring.
cons: Low pay for the work involved.

pros: Great benefits, and new president is trying to make things more transparent and data driven. Free tuition, though it can be hard to get into the classes you want.
cons: Going through reorganization / restructuring with new president. Sometimes uncertainty makes people uneasy.

pros: There is a variety of specialists working the Digital Film Lab at Emerson. I learn from my coworkers every day and we share our work with each other.
cons: Not much vertical movement available for students, but that is to be expected.

pros: Creative environment, friendly co-workers.
cons: Not competitive pay compared to other Boston area colleges. Not providing sufficient staff training and development program.

pros: I've worked here for over 10 years and have loved it.  The students are great and I'm lucky enough to have  wonderful boss.
cons: School is expanding so money is tight and is going towards property acquisition and expansion.

review_title: Great benefits in a very creative environment
pros: Emerson offers great benefits in a very unique environment with tons of resources for learning in a very welcoming community.
cons: Depending on the department, growth in the institute might not be an option.

pros: Good work environment, interesting projects.
cons: Administration for the whole college is done by far too few people, leading to difficulties.

pros: Great work life balance and benefits.
cons: Poor compensation and no changes in foreseeable future.

review_title: Does not weed out bad management
pros: Great campus life. Students do interesting work, and it's energizing to be around that.
cons: Poorly qualified management who played favorites and did not care about the merits of our work.

pros: Top 10 film school in the country, access to opportunities exclusive to the institution.
cons: Incredibly expensive causing severe lack of diversity and inclusion.

Great Management
cons: Big Staff, hard to find shifts if you don't get them when they come out.

cons: working with accounting supervisor, cashier and closest departments.

cons: Can be too "academic" with too many meetings. Turnover of department heads can be an issue.

pros: The reputation of its brand.
cons: Administration is unsure of where it is going; slow responses.

pros:

pros: School is right downtown. Co-workers were good, administrators were very nice.

pros: Bright and talented colleagues, great resources, devotion to excellence in their academic fields.
